Mrs. Sophorn P. (pictured above) and her husband, Mr. Belasambath Nong, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have three daughters. Two are garment factory workers and another is in school.  

Sophorn is a weaver. Her husband is a government official. He works at the Department of Inspection. Sophorn is asking for a loan of 1,200 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Musso

texts.ru: Темиров Муссо житель Яванского района. Возраст, 37 лет. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Образование-среднее. Занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Он в основном откармливает и продает крупнорогатый скот. Этим видом деятельности занимается 8 лет. Кредит берет для закупа мелко-рогатого скота.
texts.en: Musso T. lives in the Yavan region. He is 37 years old. He is married and has four children. He has secondary education and does animal husbandry. Musso breeds cattle at home, he mainly feeds and sells small horned cattle. He has been in this business for eight years. The loan is to buy small horned cattle.

loans.use: to buy small horned cattle

loans.name: Dulamsuren

texts.en:
Dulamsuren is 37 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger slum district (Mongolian tent dwelling district) of Ulaanbaatar, in their small family house. Her daughter is a student and the young son attends a kindergarten. Her husband is an electrician and works for a construction company. 

In 2004 Dulamsuren completed a certified manicuring and pedicuring course, and two years ago she started renting a small area inside a beauty shop and opened her manicuring business. The area where she operates is well crowded and her business is doing very well. With this loan she is planning to renew her old equipment by buying a new table, chair, nail polisher, a dryer and some colored lacquers.

loans.use: to buy a new table, chair, nail polisher, dryer and some colored lacquers.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Aside from having an entrepreneurial spirit, Rosalie C., 35, has a strong mother intuition. Rosalie was not able to finish her courses in college, but her involvement in CCT* enabled her to build her own small business. She is now married to a driver named Arnel, and together they have four dependents. One is in high school, two are in elementary, and one is not yet studying. Together they live in Libertad, Pasay City.

Rosalie buys and sells accessories for a living. She has a space in the commercial area of their community in Libertad. There she displays her personally chosen accessories, which she hopes are fashionable enough to catch the attention of potential buyers. Rosalie has been selling accessories for fifteen years now, and she does it without the help of an employee. Monthly she and her husband are able to earn about $295.

To help her grow her business, Rosalie is borrowing an amount of 21,000 PHP to be able to purchase stylish accessories for sale. She acknowledges that the loan will help her in revolving the finances of her business. With this loan, she is able to buy huge quantities of stock and meet her family's daily needs as well.

One challenge Rosalie faces is the number of customer debts. Also, sometimes the daily sales are low. Another challenge is that her eldest child is beginning to keep bad company in school. She thus prays that she would have the time to focus on the studies of her children and keep them from bad influences. It is her earnest desire to bring them closer to the Lord. She also would like to have her own commercial space.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase stylish accessories for sale

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is 36 years old and married with two children.

Mary Ann works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Mary Ann has borrowed and paid back three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for six years and also earns an income from the sale of gasoline and electronic re-loading.

Mary Ann aspires to send her children to college and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tabib

texts.ru:
Tabib S. 28 let, on jenat i imeyet odnoqo rebonka. On yavlyayetsya IDP personom , pereselenec iz Lachin regiona, seychas projivayet v qorode Baku vmeste so svoyey lubimoy semyoy.
Tabib uj 3 qoda kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom prodaji koncelyarskix tovarov( tetradi,ruchki,knigi i t.d). Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi uvelichit pomesheniye svoyeqo magazina dlya toqo chtobi razmestiti bolshe tovarov. Ranshe Tabib rabotal v takom magazine prodavcom seychas uje on imeyet svoy sobstvenniy magazin.
texts.en: Tabib S. is 28 years old.  He is married and has one child.   He is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person).  He is a refugee from the Lachin region who now lives in Baku with his beloved family.  Tabib has been selling office supplies for three years (notebooks, pens, books, etc.).  Now he needs 2000 AZN to increase the size of his shop so he can offer more goods.  Tabib used to work for a shop like this one, but now he owns his own shop.

loans.use: to increase the size of his shop

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen is 46 years old and married with five children.

Aileen works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Aileen has borrowed and paid back seven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 12 years and also earns an income from operating an eatery/carenderia.

Aileen aspires to expand her business and continue the education of her child.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rene

texts.en:
Rene is 44 years old and married, with 2 children, 7 and 9 years old. He lives in Surallah, South Cotabato with his family.

Rene is a farmer who owns land in his town. He tills his land and prepares it well for cropping. Rene grows rice that he sells to his community. He usually earns about 3,000 PHP from his farming. Rene also owns a sari-sari (variety) store that his wife manages. They sell noodles, canned goods and other kinds of products. Rene says that the store helps the family with their daily needs.

Rene has requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and additional merchandise to sell. He is hopeful that this loan will help his businesses to grow.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and merchandise to sell

loans.name: Koem An

texts.en:
Mrs. Koem An was born in 1977.  She is married to Mr. Ret and they have three children --  two are attending the local public school and one is still too young to work or study.  

Mrs. Koem An and her husband are farmers who own a 1.50-hectare plot of land where they cultivate rice to sell as well as to eat.  Mr. Ret is a also construction worker. 

Although they try to work hard, they can earn only a small income.  To improve this condition, Mrs. Koem An is applying for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn G., 28, continually ventures into selling various kinds of products in order to make her business thrive. Although Analyn only has high school education, she is ever determined to succeed in life. She is married to William, a taxi driver, and they have a child who attends elementary school. They used to live in Naga City in the lower part of Luzon, but now they live in Caloocan City, Metro Manila.

Direct selling is one source of income for Analyn. She distributes catalogs of famous beauty brands in her community, gets orders from friends and neighbors, buys these orders from the sales office, and delivers them to customers for a commission. However, her focus as of the moment is selling corn near their community in Kiko, Camarin. She has been selling corn for six years and is able to earn PHP 7,280 monthly.

To help her continue operating her businesses, Analyn is requesting a PHP 26,000 loan. She will use this money to buy essential ingredients to sell corn, such as corn, sugar, and margarine. She also plans to expand her business by selling other nutritious food such as sweet potatoes, peanuts, Indian mangoes, and bananas. The loan will benefit her greatly as it serves as the finances to sustain such business ventures.

Vacations are difficult for Analyn's business, as they are to other micro-entrepreneurs' businesses, since there are fewer customers. Nevertheless, Analyn works hard to make sure she helps her family with its daily needs. She continually looks for innovations or expansion in her business, because the bottom line is that she wants to become successful.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase essential ingredients for corn selling

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhom is a 42-year-old mother of six children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a farmer, and the others are studying in the local public school. She and her husband, Mr. Sovan, are farmers who own a 2.60-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell as well as to eat.  Mr. Sovan also works as a fisherman and a farming laborer. 

In the rice field, Mrs. Sokhom has a problem because her field is far away from the irrigation system.  To improve her rice production, Mrs. Sokhom is asking for a loan to buy a water pump, fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide. 

Mrs. Sokhom and her husband are in the picture.

loans.use: buy a water pump, fertilizer, gas, and pesticide for her rice farm

loans.name: Savy

texts.en:
Mrs. Savy Y. (pictured) and her husband, Mr. Kimtray Leng, live approximately twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh City. They have three daughters -- one attends school and the other two are still young.

Mrs. Savy is a garment factory worker and her husband is a mason. A recipient of a previous Kiva loan, she is now requesting another loan of $1,000 to expand and improve the house where she lives.

loans.use: make improvements to her house

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is 52 years old and married, with 5 children, whose ages range from 18 to 30 years old. 

Rosita is a farmer who has been growing rice for 10 years. Her husband, who is also a farmer, mainly manages their farm. Rosita also sells fresh and dried fish. She says she buys directly from fishermen and goes around the neighborhood to sell fish. She also dries fish to sell as well.

Rosita has requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Hang

texts.en:
Mrs. Hang is married to Mr. Sothy.  They have three children -- one is a student and the others are still too young to work or study.  

Mrs. Hang is a farmer who owns a 3-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell as well as to eat.   Her husband owns an agricultural machine and rents them to farmers to earn money to support his family.  

In the rice field, Mrs. Hang has some problems because her field has infertile soil and a lot of insects.  To improve her rice production, she is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide.   

Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide for her rice farm

loans.name: Mayramkan

texts.en:
Mayramkan A. is 53 years old, married, and has two children. She worked as a baker at a local pastry shop and her husband Sultanazir worked at a carpet factory in Karabalta town. Unfortunately, their salaries did not cover all the family’s expenses, so in order to find additional means of subsistence, Mayramkan started her cattle breeding business in 1992.  

With the initial capital of 5,000 KGS, Mayramkan managed to earn about 15,000 KGS a month from selling milk and meat products. With this revenue, she was able to pay for her daughter’s wedding and give her a good dowry.

Mayramkan has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase two milk cows, which will allow her to increase her milk sales. With the additional earnings, she plans to increase her number of cattle and in the future buy a car for her family. 

About Bai-Tushum and Parners:

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: purchase two milk cows

loans.name: Seap

texts.en:
Mrs. Seap was born in 1966. She is a widow with three children who are seamstresses in garment factories. She is a farmer who owns a 1.50-hectare plot of land where she grows rice. Part of the rice yield she sells and the rest is for her family. She is a farming laborer. 

In the rice field, she has a problem because her field has infertile soil. So to improve her rice production, Mrs. Seap is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide, and with the rest of the loan, she is going to plow her field in the dry season.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide

loans.name: Sanita

texts.en:
Sanita, 53 years old, earns a living through farming. She grows rice that she sells to the people in her community. She is also a fruit vendor. She buys from other fruit sellers and resells the fruits near a school. Some of the fruits that she sells come from her garden.

Sanita has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm supplies. Sanita works hard to improve her family's living conditions. This loan will help her achieve her goal.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm supplies

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan H. knows that time is indeed of the essence, particularly in business. At 44, Susan is an active community partner in CCT* and a beginner in the retail field. She had a course in elementary education and is married to Robert, who is now retired at 61. Susan takes hold of whatever time she has to prepare for the future of her only child, who is now in high school. The family moved from the province of Bulacan to Caloocan City, which is located in the national capital region.

Susan sells accessories in her neighborhood, handpicking necklaces, bracelets and other knick knacks that would attract customers. Susan has only been in business for a year and she earns around PHP 7,800 every month. 

To help her continue operating her business, Susan is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She is planning to buy trendy accessories in bulk in order to attract neighbors, passersby, and other potential customers. This money will also be used for other necessities to improve her business. Susan has high hopes that she will earn big and be able to start on her savings, with the help of CCT.

Rainy seasons are a challenge to Susan because they hamper her business productivity. However, since they cannot be avoided, Susan devises ways to make the rainy seasons work to her advantage. She says that this and other challenges encourage her to strive more in life and earn profitably so that she can help others as well. It is her prayer to always be in God's care.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase trendy accessories

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Mrs. Neang is a married woman who was born in 1977. She and her husband have two children, both of whom are too young to work or attend school. To earn a living, she is a seamstress in a garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Munoeun, is a middleman in the chicken sales business and a pig breeder. In addition, he is a farmer who owns a small piece of land; specifically, he grows rice, some of which he sells to local consumers, and the rest of which he keeps to feed his family.

Because her husband’s business has been doing quite well, she would like to help him expand the business. Therefore, Mrs. Neang is seeking a loan in the amount of $500 to buy more piglets and pig feed, with the remaining balance of the loan proceeds to be used to buy more chickens for re-sale purposes.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets, pig feed, and chickens

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase used clothes to resell and to pay her children's school fees

loans.name: Norng

texts.en:
Mr. Norng is a married man who was born in 1986. He and his wife, Mrs. Sarun, have two children, both of whom are too young to work or study. To earn a living, he works as a fisherman. In addition, he is a farmer who owns a 3-hectare plot of land; on his land, he grows rice, some of which he sells to local customers, and the rest of which he keeps to feed his family. His wife, meanwhile, owns a general store in the local village, where she sells groceries to generate additional profits to support their family.

Mr. Norng explains that he has been experiencing problems with his rice field because it is not particularly fertile at this time. As a result, Mr. Norng is applying for a loan in the amount of $500 to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticides.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy salt, soap and sugar

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Although she didn't finish her Hotel and Restaurant Management (HRM) course in college, Shirley B., 42, refuses to give up on her future. She works on her own micro-business to make sure that she'll be better off in the end. She is married to Salvador, a customer service representative, and they have two children who are both in college. The family resides in Caloocan City.

Shirley sells frozen food to members of her local community. This type of food has a good market since a lot of people look for cheaper alternatives to fresh meat and an easier fix for a meal. Shirley chooses good quality frozen food such as sweetened pork, ham, and sausages for her well-deserving customers. Shirley also has a mineral water station. She has juggled these two businesses for four years and earns a monthly net income of around PHP 6,900.

To help her grow her business, Shirley has applied for a loan of PHP 8,000. She will add this to her current capital in order to purchase more quantities of quality meat goods to sell to her regular customers. She will also purchase more cases of mineral water for refilling. Shirley believes this loan will help her greatly increase her profits.

Shirley has the same challenges as other micro-entrepreneurs, such as irresponsible non-paying customers and tough competition. However, being a community partner in one of the fellowships in CCT* enables her to find ways to solve and overcome these issues.

As a CCT community partner, Shirley faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase meat and mineral water

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seedlings for planting and clothes to sell for the Easter season.

loans.name: Mon

texts.en:
Mrs. Mon is married to Mr. Chhem. They have three children, all of whom study at a local public school and assist with their parents’ businesses. She is a Khmer cake seller and a chicken breeder, while her husband is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land. On his land, he grows rice, some of which he sells to local customers, and the rest of which is used to feed their family.

Mrs. Mon would like to start a new business, but she does not have enough money to do so. Therefore, Mrs. Mon is applying for a loan in the amount of $325 to buy five piglets and pig feed, and the remaining balance of the loan proceeds would be used to build a pigpen.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and pig feed and to build a pigpen

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Mrs. Neang is a married woman who was born in 1987. She and her husband have two children, both of whom are too young to work or study. To earn a living, she is a chicken breeder and a farmer. Indeed, she owns a half-hectare plot of land, on which she grows rice. She explains that she sells some of the rice she grows to local customers and keeps the rest of the rice to feed her family. Her husband, Mr. Phoeun, is a fisherman and a construction worker.

Although she and her husband work very hard, they are not generating as much income as they would like. So, to improve their standard of living, Mrs. Neang would like to start a new pig breeding business. As a result, she is applying for a loan in the amount of $375 to buy some piglets and pig feed, and any remaining balance of the loan proceeds would be used to buy more chickens.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, pig feed, and chickens

loans.name: Allodalome Group

texts.en:
The Allodalome group consists of 14 women who live in the same village near the rural market town of Allada. This is their first loan with ALIDE. They have agreed to support each other in business and through loan repayments.

Ahouanvoéton (with her hand raised in the photo) is 36 years old and a widow. She independently supports two children, who do not have the chance to be in school. Since the age of 6, Ahouanvoéton has been selling palm oil, corn, and cassava from her stall in the market. This loan will enable her to purchase five drums of oil for resale. Her long term aim is to grow her sales. Her strongest points as an entrepreneur are her rigor and dynamism.

loans.use: to purchase 5 drums of palm oil

loans.name: Ainagul's Group

texts.en:
Ainagul M. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Tup, a nice village in the Isykul region. She is 56 and married. Together with her husband, she has raised two sons and a daughter. All the children are married, and, under the Kyrgyz tradition, the younger son lives with his parents. In order to earn money, the family breeds poultry and cultivates agricultural products. Selling poultry, they earn 3,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, Ainagul wants to purchase 600 kilograms of wheat seeds and some fuel for the sowing process. In the future, she wants to increase her quantity of poultry and get a good harvest. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line—People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan—at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase wheat seeds

loans.name: Faidah

texts.en:
In this world there will always be competition. This is what Faidah C., 28, learned early on. Faidah, a community partner in CCT*, reached high school and is married to Macoy, a vendor in the local community. They have three children, and as a family they reside in Tanza, Cavite.

Faidah sells sandals made of plastic. She has a store in the Epza Terminal in Tanza. She has been in this business for five years now, and she manages to run the business without the aid of any employees. Because of her diligence at work, she is able to earn approximately 12,240 PHP every month.

She has decided to apply for a 40,000-PHP loan to help her increase her daily shoe sales. She intends to use this money to purchase brand-new shoes for her store. Faidah plans to buy various designs and sizes for kids and for adults. Also, she wants to buy flat shoes, which she will incorporate into her product inventory.

Having many competitors with the same brand and products is one major challenge for Faidah. There are just so many micro entrepreneurs in her place, with the same business as her. Nonetheless, she aims to rise above the others by purchasing products that cannot be found in the other stalls. It is Faidah's dream for her business to become big and sustainable.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meetings, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for the purchase of brand-new shoes to sell

loans.name: Phy

texts.en:
Mrs. Phy N. (pictured above) is a 35-year-old widow. She has two young children: one son and one daughter. The family lives in a village off of National Road number two, approximately twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh City.

To earn a living, Phy is a garment factory worker. She is asking for a loan in the amount of $400 to build a restroom for her family to use.

loans.use: To build a restroom for her family

loans.name: Sa Em

texts.en:
Mrs. Sa Em, who was born in 1968, is a married woman. She has three children, one of whom is a barber, while another is studying in a local public school and the other does housework. 

She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she can grow rice to sell. Some part of the rice is for her family. Her husband, Mr. Suong, is a teacher. 

At present, she has a problem because her husband’s workplace is far away from his home. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Sa Em is applying for a loan to buy a new motorcycle for her husband's transportation.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Sokna

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokna A. (pictured with her loom) and her husband, Mr. Savoeurn Pork, have been married since 2006 and have one young son. The family lives in a village along the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sokna and her husband are silk weavers. The couple asked for a Kiva loan several times; they hope to continue their silk-weaving business because it is a traditional profession. So Sokna is asking for another loan in the amount of $600 to purchase weaving materials (raw silk).

loans.use: to purchase raw silk materials for her silk weaving business

loans.name: Diguihola's Group

texts.en:
Diguihola and Pascaline live in the same neighborhood of Cotonou, Benin's largest city. This is their sixth loan with ALIDE, and they support each other in business and in loan repayments.

Diguihola (with her hand raised in the photo) is 64 years old. She moved to her current neigborhood in Cotonou 18 years ago and now lives with her husband, Fachina. Their two children are now adults and have left their parents' care.

For the past 16 years, Diguihola has run a stall selling meals outside her home. This loan will enable her to purchase the raw ingredients she needs from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim in the long term is to strengthen her business. She claims to be very dynamic in her approach to business.

loans.use: to purchase corn, rice, and cooking oil for food preparation

loans.name: Catherine's Group

texts.en:
The three entrepreneurs in this group all live together in a house in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. This is their fourth loan with ALIDE, following successful past repayments.

Catherine was born in 1969 in Adjibhoun. She moved to her current neighborhood in Cotonou 12 years ago and now lives with her husband Albert and their four children, all of whom are schooled.

For the past 10 years, Catherine has run a stall outside her home, selling various foods and household goods. This loan will enable her to purchase palm oil, rice, soap, and sauces from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim in the long term is to expand her business. She claims her strength as an entrepreneur to be her ability to diversify her business to attract new clients.

loans.use: to restock her stall with palm oil, rice, soap, and sauces

loans.name: Lucienne's Group

texts.en:
The three entrepreneurs in this group all live in the same neighborhood of Cotonou, Benin's largest city. This is their fifth loan with ALIDE, following successful past repayments.

Lucienne (with her hand raised in the photo) was born in 1958 in Ganvier, north of Cotonou. She moved to her current location 12 years ago and now lives with her husband Gabriel and two of their six children.

For the past 13 years Lucienne has run a stall selling various foods and household goods in the Ladji district. This loan will enable her to purchase spices, soap, and corn from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim in the long term is to save enough to buy her own plot of land.

loans.use: to purchase bulk merchandise for resale, like spices, soap, and corn

loans.name: Maziima  Association Group

texts.en: Ziaituni N. is 38 years old and has for the last four years made a living by selling food along Kamuli road in Jinja. At her stall, she mostly sells staple foods such as rice, bananas and sweet potatoes plus charcoal. Originally, she sold sweet potatoes only but as her finances improved she decided she wanted to diversify and sell some other foods. Zaituni is happily married, has eight children and earns 30,000 shillings a week as profits. She plans to use her portion of this group loan to buy more rice, bananas, charcoal and sweet potatoes to resell.

loans.use: To buy more rice, bananas, charcoal and sweet potatoes to resell

loans.name: Doflintien's Group

texts.en:
The five entrepreneurs comprising this group know each other through common business, as they all run general stores in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. This is their third loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments.

Doflintien (with her hand raised in the photo) was born in 1980 in Cotonou. She moved to her current location 10 years ago and now lives with her husband Ségbègnon and their four children. For the past five years Doflintien has run a stall selling general food and household goods. This loan will enable her to purchase a new stock of spices, bags of rice, and corn. Her aim in the longterm is to diversify her business. She says she is very dynamic in her approach to business.

loans.use: to purchase food stock for resale

loans.name: Awacou

texts.en: Awacou was born in 1957 in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. She now lives in the Agbato district with her husband Latifou and two of their four children. For the past 11 years, Awacou has sold firewood directly from her home. This is her sixth loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments. This loan will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim is to further strengthen her business.

loans.use: to purchase wood for resale

loans.name: Zinakan's Group

texts.en:
Zinakan K. is the leader of this group. She is 54 and married to a farmer. The family lives in Bokonbaevo, a nice village on the south shore of Isykul Lake. In order to earn money, Zinakan takes orders and provides sewing services. She has been operating this service for 13 years and earns 6,500 KGS monthly.

The family also cultivates agricultural products to make additional money. Zinakan has applied for a loan since the sowing process begins in the spring. She needs money to purchase fuel and a variety of seeds. In the future, Zinakan dreams of building a big new house. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel and seeds

loans.name: Elise

texts.en:
Elise was born in 1964 in Abomey, a major historical town in Benin. She moved to Cotonou, Benin's largest city, 15 years ago. She lives with her husband, Daniel, and two of their four children. All of their children are schooled.

For the past 13 years, Elise has sold meals from her stall in the Sama-Lémé district. This is her 8th loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments. This loan will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. She cites her proactivity as her greatest attribute as an entrepreneur.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to prepare food

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma L., 33, is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Angelito L., a bus driver, and is the mother of a young boy now at preparatory school. By the grace of God, Gemma has managed to support her child's schooling and she is now working hard to be able to send him all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Gemma, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave their children.

Gemma maintains a direct sales business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through popular direct selling brands such as Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and others. A customer's order is paid for in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer, who has a one-month-to-pay credit. Since dealers’ cost prices are lower than those in the catalog, they earn profit on the price difference. Gemma's regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 700 in sales every week.

To help her continue operating her business, Gemma is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan, which she will use to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Gemma dreams of being able to give her child a good, high quality education through all her hard work in her business. 

As a CCT community partner, Gemma faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for cosmetics and other items ordered in advance by her customers

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 35 years old and lives in the Ahouassa district of Cotonou, Benin's largest city. She is married to Romuald and they have four children, all of whom have left home.

For the past 9 years, Marie has sold jewelry as a traveling saleswoman. This is her fifth loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments. This loan will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim is to strengthen her business in the short term.

loans.use: to purchase jewelry items for resale

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine, a 41-year-old resident of the Agbato district of Cotonou, Benin's largest city, is married to Lazare, and they have one child who has left home. For the past 12 years Josephine has been a seamstress. This is her sixth loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments and will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim is to strengthen her business in cloth sales.

loans.use: to purchase bolts of cloth and sewing material

loans.name: Bros

texts.en:
Mr. Bros K. (pictured here) is 41 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sophat Khun, is 44 years old.  They live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, approximately 25 kilometers away.  They have been married since 1995 and have three sons. Two are in school and another one is still young.   

Bros sells cows and oxen. He buys them from other provinces far away from his house and resells to a slaughter house. Sometimes, there is a middleman who comes to buy at his house. His wife is a garment factory worker. 

Bros is asking for his first loan of $700 to purchase additional cows and oxen for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional cows and oxen for resale.

loans.name: Sokan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokan C. (picture above) has five children - two sons and three daughters. Two are garment factory workers, two attend school, and another one is still young. The family lives in a village about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokan stays at home. Her husband is a soldier. The main source of income is from her husband and children’s salaries. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to work.

loans.name: Rutabo Twimukye Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
Didas G. is the leader of Rutabo Twimukye group in Kyenjojo. He is 37 years old and a very hard working and innovative man, married with children. Didas is an agriculturalist and also has a bodaboda service which he bought over two years ago to transport people to their destinations at a fee. He grows matooke, beans and other produce, while his boda services all in Rutabo – Bwizi; each enterprise earns him a daily income of 30,000/=.

A self-starter who hopes to continue expanding his businesses to greater heights, Didas now needs a loan to buy more produce such as beans, maize and matooke to stock in his business.

loans.use: to buy more produce including beans, maize and matooke to stock in his business.

loans.name: Adelaide

texts.en: Adelaide is 45 years old, married, and has one child who attends school.  They live in the Adogleta district of Cotonou, Benin's largest city. For the past 15 years, Adelaide has run her stall selling various foods and household goods. This is her eighth loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments. This loan will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim is to open a shop in the future.

loans.use: To purchase stock items to sell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita F. is 57 years old, married, and has four children ranging in age from 18 to 31.  Anita is a farmer working in Surallah, South Cotabato. She grows rice and corn to sell. She also makes chorizo that she sells in her neighborhood. Anita works hard to sustain her family and her children's education. She wants them to be successful.  Anita's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: 0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Minh L. T. (42) is a 59-year-old woman living in the town of Hoang hoa - Thanh hoa. Minh is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa (0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa).

Minh is married and has 3 adult -aged children. She operates a family member's business raising livestock, primarily chickens, for saL.. Minh has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month from it.

In 2004, Minh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minh has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000,000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women, which was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. She is now requesting a new loan of 7,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 6th loan Minh has taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  Tham L. T. (76) is a 29-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

2.  Vien L. T. (63) is a 57-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business.

3.  The L. T. (41) is a 54-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

4.  Nhung L. T. (58) is a 51-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

5.  Cuc L. T. (60) is a 54-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,000,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Minh L. T. (42) là 59 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang hoa - Thanh hoa.  Minh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa (0306042 Quang Trung - Hoang Thanh - Hoang Hoa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán.  Minh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 6 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Minh kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND.  Vào 2004, Minh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Minh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5,000,000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 6th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Tham L. T. (76) là 29 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Vien L. T. (63) là 57 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


3.  The L. T. (41) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Nhung L. T. (58) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


5.  Cuc L. T. (60) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase more livestock

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel R., 55, is a resident of Carmona, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Elreytrio, a consultant, and is the mother of six young adults; two already work and four are still at home. By the grace of God, Maribel has managed to support all her children’s educational needs and she is still working hard to maintain her finances.

Maribel operates an auto-repair shop.  She hires mechanics while she handles the finances, accounts, inventory and promotions. The shop offers repair, check-up and beautification of all types of cars and jeepneys - any type of referred vehicle. There is also a little refreshment stand in the auto-repair shop, where they sell beverages to waiting customers and passing passenger vehicles.

To help her continue operating her business, Maribel is requesting a PHP 11,000 loan, which she will use to buy an additional welding machine and other supplies such as spare car parts, wiring, putty paint, etc. Maribel expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Maribel dreams of being able to have a good and comfortable life through all her hard work in her business and to be able to purchase her own car someday. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy another welding machine and supplies

loans.name: Bienvinida

texts.en:
Bienvinida, 55 years old, is already a widow and has 7 children to support. Her oldest child is 36 years old and the youngest is 17. Bienvinida has children who still go to school.

Bienvinida is a farmer who grows rice to sell to the people in her community. She also owns and manages a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells sugar, detergent soap and other products. This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and merchandise to sell

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad is a farmer working in Surallah, South Cotabato. She has been growing rice for 20 years, selling her harvest to the people in her community. Caridad also runs a sari-sari (variety) store, selling vinegar, oil, biscuits and other products. She says the store is very helpful in meeting her family's daily needs. Caridad works hard to improve her businesses and sustain her family. She has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and additional merchandise to resell.

Caridad is 46 years old, married and has 7 children, whose ages range from 18 to 27 years old.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and merchandise to resell

loans.name: Savet

texts.en:
Mrs. Savet K. (pictured with her loom) and her husband, Mr. Som-ol Chab, are silk weavers. Besides weaving, Som-ol is also a construction worker.  They have eight children - two sons and six daughters. Four are married and live in their own family homes, one is a garment factory worker, two weave silk at home, and another one is a construction worker. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Mrs. Savet K. asks for another loan of $1,100 to continue her weaving business by purchasing silk and cotton materials.

loans.use: to purchase materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Mugoma Feed The Family Group A In Kyenjojo

texts.en:
K. Yosam is the leader of the Mugoma feed the family group A in Kyenjojo. He is 60 years old and married with 6 children, 4 of whom are still in school. Yosam is a farmer who grows and sells produce such as maize and beans. He operates from Mugoma and works with his wife and eldest two children. He has grocery stores in Kyenjojo and is able to make a weekly profit of 70,000 UGX.

Yosam grew up in a farming household and his first business was growing fresh foods and vegetables 20 years ago, and he still grows them to get more income. His dream is to be able to put up a big store in Kyenjojo with the help of loans. He is happy that the same loans have enabled him to buy more land for agriculture. Yosam needs this loan to buy stock produce.

loans.use: to buy more stock produce such as maize and beans

loans.name: Chantal's Group

texts.en:
Chantal (with her hand raised in the photo) is 28 years old and lives with her husband, Maurice, and their two children in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. Both of their children are in school.

Chantal belongs to this loan group consisting of 34 women who all live in the same neighborhood. This is their first loan with ALIDE. They have agreed to support each other in business and through loan repayments.

Chantal runs a stall selling cloth and other sewing materials. This loan will enable her to purchase bolts of cloth from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Chantal’s strongest point as an entrepreneur is her rigor in finances and accounting. Her aim in the long term is to strengthen and diversify her business.

loans.use: To purchase bolts of cloth for resale

loans.name: Merciditha

texts.en:
Merciditha is a 44-year-old married woman with three children, one of whom is in school. Merciditha works very hard to provide for them.

Merciditha runs a sari-sari (general) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store.

Merciditha has been in this business for 20 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, sardines, curls, laundry soap, candies etc. 

In the future, Merciditha would like to repair her house and save for emergency purposes.

loans.use: to purchase additonal stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en: Mrs. Sitha C. (who we see in the photo) makes a living as a weaver and her husband, Mr. Det Sam, makes a living building houses. They have been married since 1980, have two married daughters and live on an Island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. Mrs. Sitha C. hopes to continue her weaving business and has applied for a loan of $300 to buy the supplies she needs to make this happen.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her weaving business.

loans.name: Sochul

texts.en:
Mrs. Sochul was born in 1984. She is a married woman who has three children, one of whom is attending a local public school, while the others are too young to work or study. 

She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she can grow rice. She sells part of the rice and the rest is for her family. Besides farming, she is also a chicken breeder. Her husband, Mr. Ten, is a laborer. 

In order to improve her family’s income, she wants to start a new business, but she does not have enough money to support it. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Sochul is asking for a loan to buy two piglets for breeding.

loans.use: to buy two piglets for breeding

loans.name: Benkola  (Soyons D’Accord) Group

texts.fr:
Benkola est un regroupement de femmes  quartier Koko de la ville de Koutiala qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, sont  toutes mariées et sont mères en moyenne de  5 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, les habillements,  les céréales  les légumes, les condiments de toutes sortes etc. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 ans. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Ramata Koné est un membre du groupe Benkola qui vend des habillements de toutes sortes : bazins, pagnes wax et des bogolans.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des pièces de bazins et pagnes wax à Bamako et des tissus à Bobo Dioulasso. Elle vend  ces articles en gros, en détail, à crédit et au comptant, au grand marché de Koutiala, à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Benkola comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 140 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Ramata Koné, compte réaliser 160 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcée ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Benkola is a group of women in the Koko district of Koutiala who live in large traditional families. They are all married and on average are 40 years old with 5 children.  This group of women sell various items such as clothing, grains, vegetables, and all sorts of condiments etc. In order to increase the size of their businesses, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program two years ago. This is their fourth group loan and all previous loans have been fully repaid.  Ramata Koné is a member of the Benkola group who sells all kinds of clothing made from damasks, wax pagnes (a wax-dyed fabric) and bogolans (hand-dyed fabric). She plans to use her loan to buy pieces of damask and wax pagne in Bamako and some fabrics in Bobo Dioulasso. She sells these items wholesale or retail, for credit and cash, at the Koutiala Grand Market to a diverse and varied clientele.
While the other members of the Benkola group hope to make an average profit of 140,000 CFA each during this cycle, Ramata Koné hopes to make 160,000 CFA. In addition to repaying the loans, they will use  part of their  income to provide for their families’ everyday expenses.They want to see this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso strengthened so that their stock doesn't become scarce.

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: 12 Hoang Thinh - Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
"Hoa Hoang Thi (43) is a 53 year-old female living in the town of Hoang hoa - Thanh hoa.  Hoa is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 08.04.12 Hoang Thinh - Hoang Hoa.

Hoa is married and has 2 adult children.  To making a living, Hoa operates a family member's business venture running a general store.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Hoa has been engaged in this business for over 7 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2003, Hoa joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Hoa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000,000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  The loan will be the 7th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Hoa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Thong Vien thi (45) is a 61 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  Quy Nguyen Thi (44) is a 56 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a fishing business.


3.  Hoa Hoang Thi (9) is a 41 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


4.  Hoan Le Thi (2) is a 36 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


5.  Son Le Thi (56) is a 37 year-old female who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Hoa Hoang Thi (43) là 53 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang hoa - Thanh hoa.  Hoa là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành V..  Mặc dù mỗi thành V. trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành V. trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 0804012 Thon 4 - Hoang Thinh - Hoang Hoa (0804012 Thon 4 - Hoang Thinh - Hoang Hoa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại sản phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Hoa thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 7 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Hoa kiếm được khoảng 2,000,000 VND.  Vào 2003, Hoa đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Hoa đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5,000,000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 7th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Thong Vien thi (45) là 61 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Quy Nguyen Thi (44) là 56 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


3.  Hoa Hoang Thi (9) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Hoan Le Thi (2) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


5.  Son Le Thi (56) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to baby livestock to raise

loans.name: Girlie

texts.en:
Not having finished her course on nursing in college, Girlie A., 31, refuses to give up on her future. She works on her own micro business to make sure that she'll be better off in the end. She is married to Renante and they are blessed with seven children, three of whom are already working.  The other four are at home. Their family resides in Carmona, Cavite.

Girlie has a mineral water refilling business.  She also sells liquefied petroleum gas tanks and rice.  She also rents out four rooms for local transients and bed spacers.  In addition, Girlie manages her direct selling business of cosmetics, apparels, footwear and accessories. She has juggled these businesses for years now, and monthly she earns an estimated net income of around Php10,000.

To help her grow her businesses, Girlie has applied for a loan worth Php14,000. She will add this to her current capital in order to be able to purchase more cases of mineral water, additional LPG tanks, and sacks of rice. Girlie believes this loan will help her greatly in increasing her profits.

Girlie has the same challenges as the other micro entrepreneurs, such as irresponsible non-paying customers and tough competition. But being part of the fellowships in CCT* as a community partner enables her to find ways to solve and overcome these issues.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: additional cases of mineral water and three tanks of liquified gas

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is a 56-year-old married woman with seven children, one of whom is in school.  Patricia works very hard to provide for them.

Patricia runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock.

Patricia has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as soft drinks, sardines, noodles, soap, eggs, bread etc. 

In the future, Patricia would like to save for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Diolita

texts.en: Diolita is a 55 year-old married woman who lives in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato, with her family. She is engaged in farming and hog-raising businesses. She grows rice and corn that she sells to the market. The pigs she raises are for fattening and sale as well. She has requested a loan to purchase feeds and fertilizers. Diolita works hard to improve her businesses and her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Ambroisine's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of 19 women who live in the same neighborhood in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. This is their second loan with ALIDE following successful repayment of the first. They have agreed to support each other in business and through loan repayments.

Ambroisine (with her hand raised in the photo) is 36 years old and lives with her husband and their two children, both of whom are in school.

For the past five years, Ambroisine has run a general store selling various items from beauty products to clothes to refreshments. This loan will enable her to purchase these items in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim in the long term is to further diversify her product line.

loans.use: to restock her shop with household goods and clothes

loans.name: Cheat

texts.en:
Mr. Cheat K., 30, is single.  He has one sister and six brothers.  He lives along National Road No. 1 approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Cheat is a fisherman. He is asking for his first loan of $200 to purchase a boat motor to repair his boat.

loans.use: purchase a boat motor to repair his boat

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a married woman with six children, all of whom are grown ups. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, Mwanatumu has operated a boda boda (motorcycle) business.  Her potential customers are neighboring community members.  Mwanatumu dreams of expanding and purchasing a car for a taxi business in the future. 

With the loan for Kshs 80,000 that she is requesting, Mwanatumu wants to purchase a new motorcycle for her business. She decided to work with Yehu Microfinance to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: purchase a new motorcycle for her transport business

loans.name: Bendiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bendiya est composé de six femmes mariées majoritairement  dans des ménages polygames avec en moyenne 45 ans et 4 enfants par femme. Elles habitent le village Dougounikoro dans la commune rurale de Sanando, préfecture de Barouéli dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage. Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente de céréales (mil), gousses d’arachide grillées, grillades de farine de blé, d’ustensiles de cuisine (tasses inox et seaux) et du bois de chauffe. 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce afin de faire leurs achats au comptant, les membres du groupe ont rejoint  Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 5ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Magnini  C. a une grande réputation auprès des filles fiancées dans, la vente des meilleures qualités de tasses inox dans le village. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter deux douzaines de tasses inox en gros au grand marché de Ségou. La vente se fait au comptant et à crédit au village et en ambulant dans les villages voisins à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes. Madame Magnini  C. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25 000FCFA qui sera réinvesti dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The Bendiya group is composed of six married women, living mainly in polygamous families. They are on the average 45 years old, with four children each. They live in the Dogounikoro village in the rural community of Sanando, Barouéli prefecture in the Ségou region (the fourth administrative region of Mali) and they know each other as neighbors and relatives by blood or marriage. The group members buy and resell millet, raw grilled peanuts, cakes from wheat flour, kitchen utensils (drinking cups of the Inox brand and buckets) and heating wood.

Needing to increase their working capital in order to be able to buy their stock for cash, the group members joined Soro Yiriwaso, and are now on their 5th solidarity loan cycle. 

Mrs. Magnini C. is well-known among the local women about to get married as the vendor of Inox cups of the highest quality in her village. She plans to use  her  loan to purchase two dozens of Inox cups wholesale at the big market of Ségou. She sells for cash and on crdit in the village and as a an ambulant vendor in the nearby villages, to a customer base usually composed of women. Mrs. Magning C. hopes to achieve a montly income of 25,000 West African francs, which will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase Inox drinking cups

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey R. is 47 years old and her husband, Mr. Sos Yin, is 44 years old.  They have been married since 1991 and have three sons and two daughters -- four are in school and one is still young. The family lives along National Road Number One, about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh.  

Srey and her husband are rice farmers. When she is not at the farm, Srey also sells cakes in her village to earn additional income. Srey wants to launch a new business selling groceries to generate much more income.  Hence she is applying for her first loan of $500 to build a grocery store and to buy grocery items for her inventory.

loans.use: open a grocery store

loans.name: Yiriwa Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Yiriwa est composé de six femmes mariées majoritairement  dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 39 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent le village Dougounikoro dans la commune rurale de Sanando dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage. 
Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de galettes à base de mil,  de céréales (mil), de gousses d’arachide grillées, d’ustensiles plastics et du bois de chauffe. 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 5ème  cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Djènèba Touré compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 3 sacs de mil au village avec les producteurs de céréales pour la transformer petit à petit en galettes. 
Pour faire de la galette, on décortique le mil, le débarrasse du son, le lave, le fait moudre, le mélange avec la  farine du blé et de la levure avant de le pétrir avec de l’eau simple. On  laisse au repos la pâte obtenue pendant 5 heures de temps au moins avant de la frire avec de l’huile. 
La vente se fait au comptant et à crédit à la porte de la concession tôt le matin à une clientèle mixte. Madame Djènèba Touré espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux petits besoins du foyer et réinvestir dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The Yiriwa group is made up of six married women, the majority of whom live in monogamous families; they average 39 years of age with four children each. They live in the village of Dougounikoro in the rural commune of Sanando in the Ségou region (Mali's fourth administrative region), and got to know each other through neighbors, relatives and via marriages. 

The group members have small businesses making and selling pancakes made out of millet, as well as trading in cereals (millet), grilled peanut pods, plastic utensils and firewood. Since they needed to increase their business, the group members decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their fifth group loan. 

Mrs. Djènèba Touré is planning on using her loan to buy three sacks of millet from cereal producers in the village, in order to make them up progressively into pancakes. 

In order to make the pancakes, one has to husk the millet, dispose of the bran, wash it, grind it, mix it with the wheat flour and yeast before kneading it with plain water. One leaves the dough to rest for at least five hours before frying it in oil. 

She sells the pancakes for cash and on credit at the concession gate early in the morning to a diverse customer base. Mrs. Touré is hoping to make an average monthly profit of 20,000FCFA with this loan and this will be used to provide for small household needs and to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to purchase millet

loans.name: Mugoma Feed The Family Group B In Kyenjojo.

texts.en: John Rwamwenge is the leader of Mugoma Feed the Family, group B, in Kyenjojo. He is 31 years old and married, with 3 school-aged children. He is a farmer involved in the sale of produce like maize, beans and fresh foods and vegetables. He operates from Mugoma and works with his wife.  His major customers are wholesale grocery owners. He is able to make 50,000/= as weekly profits. John began his business using savings from being a camera man and from running a retail shop seven years ago.  He does not regret the move he made, and he still runs his small retail shop. His dream is to be able to put up a wholesale general merchandise shop in Kyenjojo.  With the help of loans, John has been able to buy various pieces of land both for agriculture and for planned commercial buildings. John needs a loan to buy stock produce.

loans.use: to buy produce like maize, beans, and fresh foods for resale.

loans.name: Oyuntsetseg

texts.en: Mrs.Oyuntsetseg is 54 years old and lives with her husband and grandson in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her grandson attends a secondary school and her husband helps in her business. She operates a game room which has PC games, a snooker table and ping pong tables. She has a plenty of customers because her business is located in the basement floor of a small shopping center and there is a secondary school nearby. Children come to play  PC games and table tennis because not many families can afford to have Internet or PC at home. Oyuntsetseg is planning to improve the game room condition, adding a restroom and putting up walls to separate the PCs from ball games. She is asking for a loan to build a restroom and walls and to replace the green cover of the snooker table.

loans.use: to build a restroom and walls, and to replace the green cover of snooker tables in game room.

loans.name: Djama Kanou Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe Tièssiri sont mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogames avec en moyenne de 36 ans, 3 enfants et habitant toutes le quartier Médine dans la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de leurs activités commerciales au marché Médine Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de jus locaux, potasse, gingembre, poudre de pain de singe et calebasses. 
Dans le but de satisfaire la clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elles ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 6ème cycle de prêt solidaire. 
Madame Kadidia D. est une vendeuse de poudre de pain de singe dans le marché Médine Ségou. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  500kg de poudre de pain de singe. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages de Dougabougou, Binguebougou et Guassola. Elle revend  à domicile et au  marché Médine Ségou. Sa clientèle est  composée essentiellement de femmes.  Elle vend au comptant et à crédit. Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 26.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour assurer l’entretien des enfants et contribuer à certaines dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Tièssiri group all married group, mainly living in monogamous families. They are on the average 36 years old, with three children, and all live in the Médine district in the town of Ségou (the fourth administrative district of Mali), and they know each other as neighbors, relatives as well as through their common commercial activities at the Médine  market in Ségou.

The group members sell local juices, potash, ginger, powdered baobab fruit and gourds. In the goal of meeting the ever growing dcustomer emand, they joined Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their 6th solidarity loan.

Mrs. Kadidia D. sells powdered baobab fruit at the Médine  market in Ségou. She plans to use her goal to purchase 500 kg of powdered baobab fruit. She stocks up in the villages of Dougabougou, Binguebougo and Guassola. She resells out of her home and at the Médine market in Ségou. Her customer base is composed mainly of women. She sells for cash and on credit. She hopes to achieve an average monthly income of 26,000 West African francs, which will be used to provide for her children’s needs and contribute to some of the family expenses.

loans.use: to purchase powdered baobab fruit

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny C. (pictured at home) and her husband, Mr. Thorn Som, have been married since 1977. They have six children – three sons and three daughters. The family lives in a village across the Mekong River, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 
Vanny and her husband are sugar cane farmers. Vanny is asking for another loan of $1,200 to purchase a sugar cane juicing machine and a motorbike for her son to carry sugar cane juice for sale.

loans.use: to purchase a sugar cane juicing machine and a motorbike for her son to carry sugar cane juice for sale

loans.name: Mihinsiensien Group

texts.en:
The Mihinsiensien group consists of 4 longstanding friends. This is their third loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments. They have agreed to support each other in business and through loan repayments.
